newsitem.title: FRANCE: Analysts revise up eastern French wheat estimate.
newsitem.headline: Analysts revise up eastern French wheat estimate.

text.p: Crop analysts in eastern France are revising up their estimates of soft wheat production after better than expected yields in the Cote d'Or area near Dijon.
But despite a 5.2 percent rise in area, both yields and production remain down the wake of a bad spring drought.
"Our soft wheat estimate is up a bit because Cote d'Or was better than we thought -- around six tonnes (a hectare) instead of 5.7," an official crop analyst at Dijon said on Wednesday.
Data is still coming in but analysts are now guessing at a regional yield of 5.8-5.9 tonnes a hectare compared with last year's 6.22 tonnes.
The previous regional target was 5.7 tonnes.
The eastern grain region, stretching from the southeastern flank of the Paris basin to the northern Alps, is France's fifth wheat producing area. The harvest ended 10 days ago.
Based on a median yield estimate of 5.85 tonnes, soft wheat output should slip 1.3 percent to 2.31 million tonnes this year.
The area sown to wheat in eastern France expanded by 5.2 percent in 1996 to 395,000 hectares.
Surveys show protein around 12 percent and test weights above 80 kilograms per hectolitre -- both considered good.
But Hagberg is reported in a wide range between 120 and 230 and Recital and Sideral varieties have been affected by pre-germination in some patches this year, analysts said.
